summary: This document is an email chain from August 2021 between a U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Task Force Officer and an Assistant United States Attorney (AUSA) regarding travel records for Jeffrey Epstein, Ghislaine Maxwell, and a third individual. The CBP officer explains that outbound travel records for the period 1990-2000 are not available in their database, as the agency did not systematically record them at that time. The officer provides available records and offers assistance for post-2000 travel data.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as one of the individuals whose travel records were searched by U.S. Customs and Border Protection at the request of the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Named as one of the individuals whose travel records were searched. The CBP officer notes she has two name variations in the records (with and without a space in her surname) and provides a consolidated spreadsheet of her travel crossings.

connections.description: Both are subjects of a coordinated travel records search requested by the U.S. Attorney's Office, indicating they are linked in the same investigation.

events.title: Period of incomplete CBP outbound travel records
events.description: U.S. Customs and Border Protection confirms that outbound travel departure records were not systematically tracked or recorded in their database during this decade.

events.title: CBP provides travel records analysis
events.description: A CBP Task Force Officer emails the U.S. Attorney's Office to report the results of a search for travel records for Epstein, Maxwell, and a third individual, explaining the limitations of pre-2000 data.

events.title: Follow-up email exchange on travel records
events.description: Email correspondence continues to confirm the search parameters and clarify the limitations of the available travel data.

keyFacts: U.S. Customs and Border Protection confirmed a significant data gap: outbound travel departure records were not systematically recorded in their database for the period 1990-2000.
The U.S. Attorney's Office was actively seeking travel records for Jeffrey Epstein, Ghislaine Maxwell, and a third individual (name not provided) as part of a case in 2021.
Ghislaine Maxwell's travel records were found under two different name variations (with and without a space in her surname), and CBP provided a consolidated spreadsheet of her crossings.
The email chain is marked as Law Enforcement Sensitive/For Official Use Only (LES/FOUO), indicating the sensitive nature of the ongoing investigation.
The correspondence shows continued investigative activity by the U.S. Attorney's Office related to Epstein and Maxwell well after their arrests and during Maxwell's trial period.
